The list of 100 roles is broad and includes positions directly targeted by these purges. While some firings (e.g., Lisa Cook) have been contested in court and are technically unresolved, others (notably McEntarfer) appear to have been executed without ongoing litigation or ambiguity. Media reports are consistent, and historical base rates under both Trump terms make it highly likely that at least one official will be out according to the resolution criteria. The only plausible way for a No outcome is for all such departures to be legally contested and unresolved through the deadline, but the number of targets and the unambiguous nature of at least some terminations make this extremely unlikely. I therefore assign a near-maximal probability.

usFederalGovernmentAffairsExecutiveBranc.forecaster_to_engage: Political Risk Analysis (US Political Risk Assessment Standards)
usFederalGovernmentAffairsExecutiveBranc.response: Your probability (8%) is implausibly low, and your reasoning underestimates the real-world velocity and aggression of Trump-era personnel actions. You're putting too much faith in legal and institutional friction, as if the courts or bureaucratic inertia can reliably stall targeted firings in the face of determined executive action—especially when the news cycle is filled with credible, multi-sourced reports of an imminent firing (Siebert) that matches the resolution criteria exactly. You claim that 'most current movements (Siebert, McEntarfer) either do not match the tracked list or are slowed by litigation,' but Siebert is, in fact, on the list and there's no reporting of any legal block or delay on his removal. The window is short, but Siebert's ouster is presented as a done deal, and the base rate for at least one out of 100 officials departing in a two-week crisis window under Trump is much higher than you allow. If your model can't see the difference between generic background risk and an explicit, well-sourced, imminent removal, you need to recalibrate. Your prediction is out of step with both the news flow and the actual mechanics of high-level removals under this administration.

politicalRiskAnalysisUsPoliticalRiskAsse.response: Your extreme probability (95%) is reckless and ignores crucial details of both the resolution criteria and the US administrative process. You treat media reporting of Siebert's imminent removal as a slam-dunk for resolution, but you fail to grapple with the legal and bureaucratic inertia that has already slowed or reversed firings this year, as seen with Lisa Cook, McEntarfer, and the mass OPM terminations. You also don't account for the possibility that Siebert's announced removal could be delayed, contested, or simply not finalized within the narrow window. While Trump has a high base rate of turnover, you overstate the predictive value of media leaks versus the actual, formal status of employment—which, per the fine print, is what matters. A 95% probability suggests near-certainty, yet the base rate for successful, court-proof removals in a two-week period is nowhere near that, even in the Trump era. You're letting headline drama blind you to the institutional stickiness and procedural friction that make the US system more resilient than your model admits.

politicalScienceEliteTheory.response: Your 22% probability is an overcautious hedge that fails to appreciate the magnitude of targeted elite action underway. You invoke historical base rates and legal friction, but you treat the current scenario—where multiple reputable outlets are reporting a specific, imminent ouster of a listed official—as just more background noise in a volatile administration. That's a mistake. Elite Theory teaches us that when a president is this overt about removing someone, especially as a demonstration of power and loyalty enforcement, the normal 'stickiness' of office dissolves rapidly. Your model would have us believe that the only relevant force is institutional inertia, but you're ignoring the potent evidence of elite coordination and signaling that makes a near-term firing extremely likely. The base rate is no longer the story when elite actors have already set the stage for removal and are broadcasting their intentions to the press. In short: you're clinging to generic turnover models and missing the very real, orchestrated purge happening in real time.

politicalScienceLeadershipTurnoverModels.response: Your 37% probability is the only one in the group that acknowledges both the unusually high risk environment and the constraining effect of legal and institutional barriers—without succumbing to headline hype or, conversely, to bureaucratic inertia dogma. You correctly highlight that the time frame is short and that procedural obstacles matter, but you don't ignore the fact that Trump’s demonstrated willingness to make rapid moves against high-level officials and the presence of credible, imminent threats (even if not all are on the list) push the risk well above the historical norm. This is the right balance: a moderate, not extreme, risk that reflects both the aggressive style of this administration and the real-world friction of contested removals. Your approach is more empirically grounded than the wild swings to 85–99% and avoids the base-rate myopia of the sub-10% crowd.

publicAdministrationBureaucraticPolitics.response: Your 99% prediction is pure maximalism masquerading as analysis. You claim that the evidence 'overwhelmingly supports a Yes,' but you gloss over the fine print that distinguishes between being fired and being formally out of position—a distinction that has tripped up several Trump removals this year. Lisa Cook and thousands of OPM firings were all announced but are still in limbo due to litigation. Even in the Siebert case, until there’s a formal announcement by the DOJ or Siebert himself within the window, the outcome is not assured. Moreover, you conflate broad patterns of administrative aggression with the actual, specific timing required by the question. The US system is built to resist exactly this kind of purge, and while your base-rate logic holds for a typical month in Trumpworld, a 99% probability is simply unjustifiable given the short window, ongoing litigation, and the fact that even 'slam-dunk' firings have been legally reversed or delayed. Save the certainty for coin flips, not for real-world bureaucracy.

publicAdministrationPrincipalAgentTheory.forecaster_to_engage: US Federal Government Affairs (Executive Branch Succession Procedures)
publicAdministrationPrincipalAgentTheory.response: Your 85% probability is overconfident given the intricate legal and administrative realities at play. You're treating the imminent removal of Siebert as if it will unquestionably satisfy the resolution criteria—but the fine print is explicit: only a formal announcement by the individual or the employer, or an unambiguous departure, counts. Recent history (Lisa Cook, mass OPM firings) shows that even the most high-profile, telegraphed removals can get stuck in litigation or procedural limbo, sometimes for weeks or months. The Trump administration's aggressive posture raises the risk, but it doesn't erase the institutional friction and legal ambiguity that have already delayed or reversed firings. In a short window like this, the probability that all the stars align—removal, no legal block, clear announcement, and no procedural gap—is much lower than your model allows. You're letting headline momentum override the actual mechanics and risks of administrative removal.

americanStudiesUsInstitutionalAnalysis.response: Your 87% probability is a classic case of overrating the drama and underrating the technicalities. You’re absolutely right that Trump’s second term is aggressive about purges, but you glide over the very real and very recent instances where firings were announced with fanfare and then frozen by litigation or institutional inertia—just look at Lisa Cook and the OPM mass firings, as you even mention! The window here is razor-thin: not only does the ouster have to happen, but it has to be formally recognized in a way that matches the resolution criteria, which the fine print makes clear is more restrictive than a headline or even an internal memo. Siebert’s case is close, but you make it sound as if mere intention or media reporting seals the deal. In reality, the system’s friction can and does delay or nullify even the boldest removals, especially when there’s legal ambiguity. An 87% call ignores the recurring lesson of the last nine months: Trump can fire, but the government doesn’t always move on his timetable.

US Federal Government Affairs (Executive.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, especially the strong consensus among most forecasters that at least one listed official (notably Erik Siebert) is about to be removed within the resolution window, I am even more confident in a Yes outcome. The critiques of the lower-probability forecasters are persuasive: the Siebert case is well-sourced, imminent, and not known to be entangled in litigation or bureaucratic delay. The base rate for at least one out of 100 officials being ousted in a high-turnover, high-conflict Trump window is substantial, and the group consensus highlights the unusually direct media evidence for a qualifying departure. The only hesitation is the always-present risk of last-minute legal maneuvering or a strategic delay of public announcement, but these are unlikely to affect all plausible cases. Therefore, I am raising my probability to reflect the near-certainty that at least one official will be out by October 1, 2025.

Political Risk Analysis (US Political Ri.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation highlighted two main points: (1) Several forecasters point to Erik Siebert—whose removal is reported as imminent in multiple reputable sources and who does appear to be on the tracked list—as a likely trigger for a Yes resolution. (2) My initial estimate arguably overweighted legal inertia and the chilling effect of recent court rebukes, while underestimating both the breadth of the listed positions and the specificity/volume of current reporting about Siebert's removal. While I still believe litigation and bureaucratic friction slow many removals (as with Lisa Cook and the mass OPM firings), these factors may be less relevant in Siebert's case. The fact that multiple, independent outlets report the administration's intent to remove him before the deadline, and that no credible reporting suggests legal action will stall it, increases the probability above my initial estimate. However, I do not find the 85%+ predictions justified, because even explicit firings are sometimes delayed or not formalized until after the window, and the history of legal and bureaucratic pushback is non-negligible. Given this, I now judge the probability that at least one listed official (most plausibly Siebert) is formally out of position before October 1, 2025, is meaningfully higher than my initial estimate, but still not overwhelming.

Political Science (Elite Theory).reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, particularly the critiques from the 'Political Risk Analysis' and 'Leadership Turnover Models' forecasters, I see no compelling new evidence that would justify lowering my probability. The points about legal friction and institutional inertia are noted, but neither forecaster provided concrete evidence that Siebert's removal is likely to be delayed, blocked, or reversed within the short window—especially given that the media reports are explicit, multi-sourced, and describe a decision that is imminent and unopposed by litigation. The only way my forecast would be too high is if all relevant announcements or actions are delayed past October 1. Given Trump's demonstrated ability to override bureaucratic obstacles when motivated, and the clear elite signaling, my extreme forecast remains justified. The small risk of a last-minute delay is already reflected in not assigning a 100% probability.

Political Science (Leadership Turnover M.reasoning_for_revised_probability: Group deliberation revealed a widespread but not universal conviction that the imminent removal of Erik Siebert is sufficient to push the probability very high. However, upon further review of the fine print and the official list provided, Siebert does NOT appear on the tracked list of 100 officials. This is a critical detail: nearly all Yes-side arguments (including the 85%, 87%, 95%, and 99% forecasts) rest on Siebert being on the list, but a careful check shows he is not. This undermines the rationale for extreme probabilities. The overall environment remains high-risk and Trump’s administration is demonstrably aggressive about removals, but absent news of a listed official being on the chopping block, the base rate for a two-week window remains low, albeit higher than in a normal administration. The best argument for a moderate increase is that the administration may try to push out another official as a demonstration of power, but there is no concrete evidence for this. Therefore, I revise my probability upward only slightly, to reflect the high-pressure context and small chance of a last-minute shake-up among the 100 roles, but strongly reject the extreme probabilities now that the Siebert error is clear.

Public Administration (Bureaucratic Poli.reasoning_for_revised_probability: Group deliberation revealed a wide spread of probabilities, but the most compelling critiques focused on the legal and procedural frictions that have delayed or blocked even high-profile Trump-era firings (e.g., Lisa Cook, OPM mass firings). The counterpoint from Political Risk Analysis and the critique of maximalist predictions highlighted the importance of formal status over mere announcements, and the risk that even well-sourced imminent removals (such as Siebert) could be delayed, fail to be formally announced, or be held in abeyance through litigation—thus not meeting the resolution criteria in the short window. While the case for a high probability remains strong given the administration’s aggressive personnel practices and credible imminent departures, the procedural stickiness of the US system and recent legal reversals argue for trimming the extremity of the forecast. Weighing these factors, I am lowering my estimate moderately, while still judging the probability to be well above 50%.

Public Administration (Principal Agent T.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation revealed a sharp divide between those who see the imminent Siebert removal as a near-certain Yes, and those who put more weight on legal friction and the fine print. The critiques of maximalist predictions (85%+) are persuasive: Siebert's ouster is not yet officially announced and could still be delayed or contested, as has happened with Lisa Cook and mass OPM firings. The defense of my original probability highlights the importance of balancing aggressive principal behavior (Trump's willingness to fire) with institutional procedures and legal barriers, especially in a narrow window. However, the cumulative weight of multiple reputable media outlets reporting Siebert's imminent removal—without any suggestion of legal challenge or delay—does tip the balance modestly higher. While extreme probabilities are still unjustified, the risk that at least one listed official is out before October 1 is slightly higher than my initial estimate, primarily due to the convergence of aggressive executive action and credible, specific reporting. I therefore revise upward to 47%.

American Studies (US Institutional Analy.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation raised valid concerns about the distinction between announced firings and an official, resolution-eligible departure. Several forecasters challenged the high probabilities (including my own) by emphasizing how recent, well-publicized removals (e.g., Lisa Cook, OPM firings) were slowed or blocked by litigation, and that the question's fine print requires unambiguous out-of-position status or a qualifying official announcement within the narrow window. While the imminent removal of Siebert still looks highly probable—and other officials may be at risk—the possibility of last-minute legal or institutional delay is non-trivial. The technical requirements for resolution (formal announcement, no pending litigation/appeal that keeps the official in the role) mean that near-certainty is unwarranted. However, the combination of credible media reports, the administration's aggressive turnover, and the sheer number of positions at risk means the probability remains very high. I am revising downward slightly to account for these procedural uncertainties.

question_details.title: Will any of these listed US federal government officials be out of their position before October 1, 2025?
question_details.description:
Donald Trump's first administration was notable for a [striking](https://www.brookings.edu/articles/tracking-turnover-in-the-trump-administration/) amount of turnover in all four years. By contrast, Joe Biden's turnover rate [was](https://www.brookings.edu/articles/tracking-turnover-in-the-biden-administration/) much lower, with Trump [saying](https://www.wsj.com/livecoverage/biden-trump-first-presidential-debate-2024-election/card/trump-knocks-biden-for-not-firing-people-bwM4mGEdjjjYg5HwlKgV?gaa_at=eafs\&gaa_n=ASWzDAiUmOXBO10XWmUng3R_zrqM9BR9qeSdR3zfF6MQ7m2AR-P20BPm-8Z8-SBTyU0%3D\&gaa_ts=68c81fb5\&gaa_sig=hGGYBoZMnGNabxhc0G0oi3qVxtuXdYbiiurZiH7JJpYh29wtQmJquKm7366ubo2H78dIPSTtOduasHthbVDAaQ%3D%3D) about Biden, "He doesn’t fire people. I’ve never seen him fire people." Trump's second term, similar to his first, has been [marked](https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/trump-turnover-2-0-tracking-whos-out-of-trumps-second-term) by sometimes rapid departures. Throughout the federal government, over 50,000 workers [had been let go](https://www.cnn.com/politics/tracking-federal-workforce-firings-dg) by the new administration as of July 2025. See also the [Trump firings tracker](https://www.citizensforethics.org/reports-investigations/crew-reports/tracking-trumps-unprecedented-often-illegal-firings-of-political-appointees-and-watchdogs/).

Terminations (e.g., being fired by President Trump) only count if the individual is out of their position as delineated in the main Resolution Criteria. For example, Lisa Cook, who Trump [said](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-fires-federal-reserve-board-member-lisa-cook/) he fired in August 2025, as of September 14, 2025 is [litigating](https://apnews.com/article/trump-lisa-cook-federal-reserve-779e2c05762400b5134cd1543b0358ae) her termination and is still [listed](https://www.federalreserve.gov/aboutthefed/bios/board/cook.htm) as a member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. Thus, she is not considered to be out of her position for purposes of this question.

Being placed on administrative leave, as has [occurred](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/stephen-volz-98b6a3b1_dear-colleagues-i-didnt-expect-to-be-communicating-activity-7355653642575572992-ZG3x/) with NOAA's Satellite and Information Systems Director Stephen Volz, does not count as long as the individual continues to be legally employed in the role. 

If a listed individual is Acting in the role, it is treated as a synonym for being in the role itself. For example, Dorothy Shea is the acting United States Ambassador to the United Nations, a position that requires confirmation by the US Senate, and for purposes of this question she is treated as being in the role. 

Promotion within the same agency, such being promoted from Deputy Director to Director, counts as long as the individual leaves the old role as defined in the Resolution Criteria.

Here are the relevant news articles:

**Government Workers, AFSCME cheer judge's ruling against Trump's firings**
U.S. District Judge William Alsup of San Francisco ruled that the Trump administration’s Office of Personnel Management (OPM) illegally terminated 25,000 probationary federal workers in February 2025. The judge’s permanent decision, while not ordering reinstatement, required OPM and the affected agencies to remove any derogatory references to the dismissals and to send formal letters to each worker stating the firings were revoked. The ruling followed a preliminary injunction that had been halted by the Supreme Court. AFGE President Everett Kelley said the decision was 'another significant victory for federal employees and for all Americans,' and praised the judge for exposing the ‘sham record’ used to justify the firings. AFSCME President Lee Saunders echoed the sentiment, noting the relief for members and the broader impact on public services. The firings, carried out between Feb. 12‑17 via a standardized OPM form letter, targeted 25,000 workers across agencies including Veterans Affairs, Energy, Defense, Agriculture, Interior, Treasury, the FAA, and others. Judge Alsup noted that OPM had directed agencies to terminate employees except those in 'mission‑critical' roles or exempted under OPM approval, a directive he deemed unlawful. The case also highlighted exemptions: the Justice Department sought relief for 10,485 workers, and the National Transportation Safety Board argued that cutting even 30 probationary workers would jeopardize investigations such as the Baltimore Harbor bridge collapse and the fatal Army helicopter crash near Washington National Airport, which involved 13 probationary investigators. The unions described the firings as 'one of the most massive employment frauds in U.S. history.'

**Trump Deputies Shrink Asylum Loophole by 65 Percent**
The article reports that President Donald Trump’s administration has reduced President Joe Biden’s asylum loophole by 65 percent, citing a 1.1 million‑case backlog that is being processed more quickly.  According to the piece, Trump‑appointed judges in July 2025 approved only 20 percent of asylum pleas—down from 57 percent in October 2023—while rejecting 75 percent of claims, up from 45 percent in October 2023.  In July 2025, the judges heard 9,830 cases, compared with 6,237 in October 2023, and granted asylum to 1,939 migrants versus 3,185 approved by Biden’s judges.  The article claims that Trump’s deputies are firing “far‑left” and Biden‑appointed judges who were “rubber‑stamping” asylum claims, and that the administration plans to replace them with 600 military judges.  It quotes Kocher, a research assistant professor at Syracuse University, saying ‘Trump has already turned the ship of the immigration courts in his first 100 days,’ and notes that the Biden administration’s asylum loophole is being closed because “Biden’s 10 million illegal migrants are losing their pleas for asylum and citizenship at record rates.”  The piece frames the changes as a policy decision that will reduce the backlog and curb “fake asylum claims.”

**Morning Brief: Biden Targeted TPUSA, Fed Finally Lowers Rates & Israel Pushes Into Gaza City**
The Daily Wire’s September 18 2025 briefing reports three major stories. First, whistleblower documents released to the Senate Judiciary Committee show that a Biden‑era FBI probe—codenamed ‘Arctic Frost’—targeted 92 Republican‑linked entities, including Turning Point USA, over a ‘multifaceted conspiracy’ to keep Donald Trump in power after the 2020 election. The investigation, begun in April 2022 under Director Christopher Wray, involved more than 150 interviews, over 400 subpoenas (300 for witness records, 200 phone selectors, 20 financial probes), and search warrants for 10 phones, 20 devices, seven iCloud accounts, 28 emails and even Trump’s Twitter. Second, Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell announced a 0.25‑percentage‑point cut to the benchmark interest rate, the first reduction since December 2024, citing a slight rise in unemployment and persistent inflation. Powell said, 'While the unemployment rate remains low, it has edged up. Job gains have slowed, and downside risks to employment have risen. At the same time, inflation has risen recently and remains somewhat elevated. In support of our goals and in light of this shift in the balance of risks, today the Federal market committee decided to lower our policy interest rate by a quarter percentage point.' The move lifted the Dow and S&P 500 to record highs and is expected to be followed by similar cuts in October and December. Third, Secretary of State Marco Rubio concluded a Middle East trip as Israel launched a ground invasion of Gaza City. Heritage Foundation VP Victoria Coates warned that the assault could complicate negotiations, noting that Hamas ‘won’t let them out’ and that neighboring countries are blocking exits. The briefing also noted an Israeli airstrike on Hamas leaders in Doha, Qatar, which the Qatari government condemned. The article cites Republican Senator Chuck Grassley, Democrat Senator Chuck Grassley, Powell, and Coates, but presents the events largely from a conservative perspective.

**Judge rules that probationary federal workers were fired illegally — AGU’s plaintiff coalition prevails**
On September 15, 2025, a federal judge ruled that the Trump Administration illegally fired tens of thousands of probationary federal employees in February. The decision made permanent a preliminary injunction issued in April 2025. The court ordered the Office of Personnel Management to update personnel records to remove false claims that the firings were performance‑based and to refrain from similar actions in the future. The ruling covers agencies such as Agriculture, Commerce (including NOAA), Defense, Education, Energy, Health and Human Services, Homeland Security, Housing and Urban Development, Interior (USGS), Treasury, Transportation, Veterans Affairs, EPA, GSA, NSF, and SBA. Janice R. Lachance, Executive Director and CEO of the American Federation of Government Employees, praised the decision, saying 'We applaud the judge’s decision and echo his striking rebuke against the clear illegality of OPM’s actions,' and added 'This outcome shows that the destruction of the scientific workforce that is so vital to our health, safety, and national security is not inevitable.'

Trump added, 'We need accurate employment numbers. I have already determined that she will be fired IMMEDIATELY and replaced by someone much more capable.' The president also criticized the revision of the employment numbers, saying, 'McEntarfer said that 73,000 jobs were added (a surprise!), but the most serious thing is the correction of 258,000 lost jobs in the two previous months. This has been happening constantly, always with negative numbers. The economy is thriving under the 'TRUMP' government, despite a Federal Reserve that is also making moves, this time with interest rates.' The unemployment rate in the US rose to 4.2% in July, according to data released by the government on Friday, 1st. These numbers indicate signs of deceleration in the labor market, with companies preparing for the impact of Trump's tariffs.

**Tracking Trump's overhaul of the federal workforce**
The Trump administration's plan to cut spending and downsize the federal government has resulted in thousands of federal workers being laid off or issued immediate termination notifications. However, hundreds of employees have had their firings rescinded or paused by court orders, although a recent Supreme Court ruling allowed the firings for more than a dozen agencies to resume. CNN is tracking the situation and has reported that the Department of Veterans Affairs has walked back its plans to conduct mass layoffs. According to CNN's analysis, which includes statements and internal memos from government officials, the approximate number of workers impacted from federal departments and agencies is subject to change. 'We are committed to transparency and will continue to update this page as new information becomes available,' said CNN. 'We are not tracking federal workers placed on administrative leave or those who take voluntary buyouts.'

summary: The forecasts from experts on whether any of the listed US federal government officials will be out of their position before October 1, 2025, reflect a range of probabilities but generally lean toward a 'Yes' resolution. Most experts recognize the Trump administration's aggressive approach to personnel management and the high rate of attempted and executed firings, especially for perceived disloyalty. Specific media reports suggesting the imminent removal of officials like US Attorney Erik Siebert are widely cited as evidence that at least one departure is likely within the window. However, several forecasters note significant countervailing factors: the short time frame for the resolution window, legal/judicial constraints that have delayed or blocked removals (e.g., Lisa Cook’s litigation), and the potential for bureaucratic inertia to push removals past the window. Probability estimates cluster at the high end (85%, 87%, 95%, 99%) among those giving greatest weight to recent turnover, direct news evidence, and historical precedent from Trump’s first term. More moderate or lower probabilities (8%, 22%, 37%) come from forecasters placing more emphasis on legal pushback, the low base rate of departures in very short windows, and uncertainty about whether ongoing firings (such as Siebert’s) directly affect individuals on the specific official list. All agree the risk is significantly above a normal administration, and all see a nonzero chance of no qualifying departure if legal or procedural barriers delay announcements or actions. In summary: While legal and technical hurdles could block some firings, the combination of explicit media reporting, Trump’s documented willingness to act swiftly, and the historically high base rate of turnover combine to make the probability of a 'Yes' outcome high to very high, unless unexpected legal blocking occurs for every targeted official.
